subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
Compare {{cog|tbq-pro|*s-na||crossbow}}, whence {{cog|duu|tana}}, {{cog|nxq|daqna}}.

{{zh-ref|Unger (1990)}} suggests a derivation from {{och-l|努|to tense; to exert}}, as the crossbow shoots arrows by releasing elastic potential energy stored in its limbs and string. {{zh-ref|Ferlus (1999)}} cites Gernet's opinion that {{och-l|砮|stone arrow-tip}} had been semantically extended to mean the whole crossbow.

More likely, {{och-l|弩}} and {{cog|tbq-pro|*s-na}} were Sinitic and Tibeto-Burman renditions of a {{w|Mainland Southeast Asia linguistic area|Mainland Southeast Asian}} Wanderwort ({{zh-ref|Ratliff, 2010}}; {{zh-ref|Blench, 2014}}), possibly of {{der|zh|aav}} origin ({{zh-ref|Norman and Mei, 1976}}; {{zh-ref|Benedict, 1990}}; {{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}). Compare other MSEA lexical items meaning "crossbow":
* {{cog|mkh-pro|*snaʔ}}, whence {{cog|vi|ná}}, {{cog|km|ស្នា}};
* {{cog|hmx-pro|*nhaᴮ}}, whence {{cog|mww|hneev}}, {{cog|ium|hnakv}};
* {{cog|tai-pro|*ʰnwɯəᶜ}}, whence {{cog|th|หน้าไม้}}, {{cog|lo|ໜ້າໄມ້}}, {{cog|khb|ᦐᦱᧉᦺᦙᧉ}}.
Also compare {{cog|map-pro|*panaq||to shoot (an arrow)}} (cf. {{cog|mkh-pro|*paɲʔ}}).
